data.title: Simple algebra
data.statement:
Kevin had his first algebra class today, but because he talked too much, the teacher gave him extra assignments. Help Kevin finish his homework quickly so he can go play Fortnite with his friends !

You are given a string [[reverse]] which value is either {{yes}} or {{no}} and a string [[s]] representing an expression consisting only of non-negative integers and the basic operators {{+}}, {{-}}, {{x}}, or {{/}}.

If [[reverse]] value is {{yes}} then the string need to be "reversed" and you must "switch" all the operators ( {{+}} becomes {{-}}, {{-}} becomes {{+}}, {{x}} becomes {{/}} and {{/}} becomes {{x}} ). 

Your goal is to output the result of the expression (reversed first if required). Division by 0 should return {{Error}}.

Only after evaluating the entire expression, round up the result if it is a floating-point number (no rounding should be performed during intermediate operations ).

<<Note :>> There will be no parentheses to define operator precedence, but we will consider that multiplication and division take priority over addition and subtraction. When evaluating operators of equal precedence, the evaluation is performed from left to right.
data.constraints:
0 < length of [[s]] < 100
0 ≤ each operand in [[s]] ≤ 2⁵³
0 ≤ absolute value of output ≤ 2⁵³ (for non-error cases)
data.stubGenerator:
read reverse:word(3)
read s:string(100)
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> A string [[reverse]] : {{yes}} or {{no}}.
<<Line 2:>> A string [[s]] representing an expression consisting of non-negative integers and basic operators separated by a space.
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1:>> A single integer representing the result of the expression (reversed first if required) given to Kevin ( round up the result when necessary ) or {{Error}} .

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Kevin had his first algebra class today, but because he talked too much, the teacher gave him extra assignments. Help Kevin finish his homework quickly so he can go play Fortnite with his friends !

You are given a string reverse which value is either yes or no and a string s representing an expression consisting only of non-negative integers and the basic operators +, -, x, or /.

If reverse value is yes then the string need to be "reversed" and you must "switch" all the operators ( + becomes -, - becomes +, x becomes / and / becomes x ).

Your goal is to output the result of the expression (reversed first if required). Division by 0 should return Error.

Only after evaluating the entire expression, round up the result if it is a floating-point number (no rounding should be performed during intermediate operations ).

Note : There will be no parentheses to define operator precedence, but we will consider that multiplication and division take priority over addition and subtraction. When evaluating operators of equal precedence, the evaluation is performed from left to right.
Input
Line 1: A string reverse : yes or no.
Line 2: A string s representing an expression consisting of non-negative integers and basic operators separated by a space.
Output
Line 1: A single integer representing the result of the expression (reversed first if required) given to Kevin ( round up the result when necessary ) or Error .
Constraints
0 < length of s < 100
0 ≤ each operand in s ≤ 2⁵³
0 ≤ absolute value of output ≤ 2⁵³ (for non-error cases)
Example
Input
no
1 + 1 - 1
Output
1
